text:
hey everyone welcome to Pai's kitchen and if you're 
not familiar with Pai's kitchen this is my second

show where I share with you all things yummy and 
delicious outside of Thai cuisine now a few weeks

ago I shared with you a Thai milk pudding on hot 
side kitchen now this week I am sharing with you

a Chinese milk pudding that is super yummy it's 
a ginger milk pudding really easy and it's a very

cool recipe so excited to get started so let's get 
started all right there are very few ingredients

in this recipe but the most important one is 
the ginger so I've got fresh ginger here and

I'm trying to get ginger juice so what I want to 
do is I'm gonna grate it if you're making a lot

you can just put it in a blender or food processor 
but I'm not making a whole lot so grating works

just fine all right that's good for now I can 
always grate a little more if I need to okay so

now I'm going to juice this ginger and you can 
just push it through a strainer like this but I

like to use a cheesecloth because I feel like 
I can get more juice out of it and there's so

much juice I can get out of here and I just love 
working with ginger just makes everything so so

fresh must get every drop all right I think that's 
good enough okay now I'm going to transfer that

and divide it into my serving cups so these are 
the cups that I am using to serve because we're

going to let the pudding set right in here and 
for each of these cups I'm going to put just a

couple teaspoons and you want to stir the ginger 
because ginger settles there's starch in here if

you don't stir it then all the starch will end 
up at the bottom right hopefully I have enough

for two come on come on come on I don't want to 
grate more just made it now that's ginger next

the milk so I've got here some whole milk I'm 
using whole milk because it's tastier but you

can do skim if you want I'm actually using lactose 
free milk because one I'm a bit lactose intolerant

and to lactose free milk is naturally a little 
sweeter so that means I don't have to add as

much sugar so speaking of sugar I'm adding just 
a little bit and you can add more if you wanted

a little sweeter now I'm going to intensify it 
with a little evaporated milk now traditionally

they don't use evaporated milk but I find the 
pudding sets a little firmer and it's a little

richer so I prefer that but you can do all whole 
milk if you want now I'm going to heat this up

just in the microwave and you can do stovetop if 
you want but I want this to be at a hundred and

fifty-eight degree Fahrenheit which is 70 degrees 
Celsius a little more a little less will work but

not much more than that so you'll definitely 
want a thermometer like this so now this is a

little bit too hot so I'm just going to wait a few 
seconds so the temperature drop and I want to make

sure all the sugar is dissolved so give it a stir 
perfect so now I'm going to just pour the milk so

I'm going to give it a stir first cuz see how the 
ginger has settled once again who knew ginger had

scars right and now the act of pouring will sort 
of mix the ginger and now I'm just gonna let this

sit do the same thing for this one alright and 
that's it that is now we wait for a few minutes

and our pudding will be ready that's right that's 
all there is to it alright so it's been about five

minutes now this is a very soft pudding okay so 
don't expect this to have like a jello consistency

it's almost like this weird state between a 
liquid and a solid it's very it's so soothing

when you eat it now the way you to test if the 
pudding is set is to place a spoon a small light

spoon please and you just gently drop it on the 
surface of the pudding that ah and if the spoon

doesn't sink then clearly it has solidified 
now I know some of you are going what what

did i just miss what is the setting agent right 
and it's actually the ginger ginger contains an

enzyme that curdles milk okay and that's why we 
needed the milk to be at a specific temperature

if it's too hot it'll denature the enzyme it's too 
cold then the enzymes aren't going to be you know

active enough to make this work I know somewhere 
you're going to be asking will this work with soy

milk or the milk substitute and as far as I know 
no because this works on casein which is a milk

protein so clearly it is not going to work in 
non milk products so if you can't have lactose

use lactose free milk like I did and this can be 
served warm or cold if you refrigerate it it will

be a little firmer but I personally prefer it warm 
I think it's so soothing so time to eat I love the

way it just kind of jiggles ever so slightly okay 
see this see how it's like barely a solid oh it's

so soothing it's almost silky and velvety but at 
the same time light heats from the ginger which

I love and a little bit of sweetness just ever so 
lightly I don't like making this too sweet because

you know the idea of it is a relaxing like spa 
food thanks Spofford amazing just amazing now I

know I always say I hope you give it a try but 
I know many of you gonna run out to the kitchen

right now and try just to see if it works because 
that's what I did the first time I just covered in

like I'm going home and I'm doing this right now 
so when you do try it send me a photo on Facebook

Twitter and Instagram and the recipe as a way 
to be on half Thai Kitchen comm if you haven't

subscribed to the show do so right here and I 
will see you next time for your next delicious
